newsitem.title: ZIMBABWE: GOLF-BUNKER PRACTICE PAYS OFF FOR VAN VUUREN.
newsitem.headline: GOLF-BUNKER PRACTICE PAYS OFF FOR VAN VUUREN.

text.p: Two days of bunker practice helped Steve van Vuuren to a share of the first round lead with fellow South African Des Terblanche in the Zimbabwe Open on Thursday.
The 37-year-old van Vuuren, who holed out twice from bunkers, collected six birdies and an eagle with only one dropped shot in his seven-under-par 65.
He was matched later in the afternoon by Terblanche, who had five birdies plus an eagle at the par-five 11th.
Namibia's Schalk van der Merwe was two shots back in third with defending champion Nick Price of Zimbabwe alone in fourth on 68.

Of the other leading names, 1992 Zimbabwe Open winner Mark McNulty and Namibia's Trevor Dodds both carded a level-par 72 while Tony Johnstone, champion in 1993, recovered from a disastrous outward loop of 40 for a one-over-par 73.
Van Vuuren said after his round that practice from the sand on the eve of the tournament had been particularly helpful.
"Although I think I'm a pretty decent bunker player, we don't have any bunkers at my home course in Nelspruit so it's not very often that I have the facility to practice," he said.
Van Vuuren, who has been farming mangoes and chillis for the past year while playing golf part-time, said the key to his round had been a steady start and some solid putting.
"I had a steady first nine, turning in 32 with no dropped shots. Then I holed a trap shot from the back bunker at the second hole for a birdie and that was the shot that really kept the day going."
Pre-tournament favourite Nick Price picked up five birdies in his 68, with his only blemish a three-putt at the par-four third.
"I hit the ball really good and only missed one green. But, although I'm putting solidly, I didn't make any of real length," Price said.
"I don't think the greens have fully recovered from the heavy rain on Tuesday...they're still soft and I felt uncomfortable on them after the pace of the greens at Sun City last week."
